Beware of fraudulent Hosts. Beware of AirBnB's tone of voice and stance (in my experience) regarding fraudulent Host damage claims lodged against the guest. Stayed for a few nights in an apartment in Milton Keynes with its own private underground parking. On arrival the apartment was in a sub standard condition with black marks on walls, scratch on TV screen, loose plug outlet. Loads of defects. Took pictures but due to busy schedule didn't have time to report or insist on a change of apartment. Some 3 hours or so after vacating the host falsely accuses me of damage and supplies similar pictures and submits a claim via AirBnB claims for ¬£300. So we now have a strong case of misrepresentation as the advert showed a pristine apartment and a strong case of false accusation. Then ensued a lengthy back and forth via email with AirBnB in me proving my innocence. The fact I had pictures and could prove when these where taken could leave no doubt of the false accusations. Interesting fact is that AirBnB paid the Host from their own insurance and told me that was due to my fantastic record with them over 9 years, but I need to read the guest terms again. So in my experience a very poor show and disregard from AirBnB from a guest perspective. Oh and just over a month later I received a car park fine for displaying a photocopied permit, which was provided by the host. Appealed and the fine was cancelled. So BEWARE there are some fraudulent people out there and as a guest AirBnB do not have your back. I have consequently deleted my AirBnB account. Never again. He who laughs last laughs the longest. Adios.

I have a short term rental and AirBnB has made up 70% of my bookings. At some point in late 2024, the bookings stopped. I am now nearing the summer when my unit is usually very booked in advance, but I have only bookings from VRBO and Booking.com and I am only 30% booked.
There is nothing wrong with my listing, no complaints, high reviews, free cancellation, and my prices are lower than comparable units. Yet, my unit is not showing up in search results and AirBnB is not helping me find out why. This issue, which seems arbitrary and algorithm related, could force me to sell which is likely to lead to a big loss of tens of thousands of dollars. I am pleading with them now to let me talk to a manager to help dig into what is happening with their search algorithms and they seem unconcerned.
AirBnB takes high fees, has no protection for hosts, and yet expects us to keep using their platform. I am already using other channels and they just don't have the same volume of guests coming through. I implore potential guests to look at other ways to book - try VRBO, Booking.com, Google... There's a lot of options, let's diversify so we don't end up maintaining this monopoly.

Account Suspended after attacked in Airbnb.

I was literally sitting in an Airbnb rental when the door was kicked in by a drug addict and I was attacked. I effectively defended myself using a kitchen knife.

Police arrested the drug addict and concluded that it was a proper self defense. I was released within two hours, only to have Airbnb permanently close my account due to 'safety reasons'.

Not only that but they cancelled all my reservations from all my guests for my own home, even though the attack took place in a totally different country and had nothing to do with the listed home.

I literally sued and they settled out of court for $4k. They refused to unsuspend the account but said I could open another, so I did.

About a month later, without talking to me or explaining, they instantly tossed my guests out again, calling them at 2am and demanding that they leave, then suspended the second account also.

I want to share the worst experience I‚Äôve ever had with Airbnb. Renting an Airbnb in Brazil turned out to be my biggest mistake.
Being human, I offered shelter to a friend at 4 AM, someone who was not included in my booking. My host, who constantly monitors his camera, saw this and took issue with it. The very next day, without even giving us 12 hours to pack, we were told to leave immediately for violating the policy of having a fourth guest not listed in the contract.
To make matters worse, the refund we received was only 30% of the total amount, despite the host previously stating it would be 50%. And Airbnb, acting as an intermediary, did nothing to help. Even squatters are given 48 hours to find accommodation, yet as paying guests, we were treated like criminals and thrown out onto the street.
Simply put, Airbnb has the worst customer service imaginable, and I regret ever using their platform.

I just got horribly scammed on Airbnb in Egypt. I rented a ‚Äúluxury‚Äù apartment in Cairo which looked amazing, light and clean in the photos. I needed the place for seven weeks. On the first day, it was clear that the apartment was super dirty, there were pieces of broken porcelain, the curtains were broken, there was a major hole in the wall and wires sticking out of the wall. It was disgusting. Before moving out, the owner confirmed with me - through Airbnb messaging - that they agreed to a full refund. So I left. But now, after I moved out, they refuse the refund. And Airbnb refuses to help me, even though the messages are clear to see in the app. I lost 2000 USD!

The property was not as nice as in the photos - pretty dingy. We couldn't bear to stay there even one night, so left and stayed in a hotel. The owner refunded some money but this is my first and last Airbnb experience - be warned that review inflation is rife and there's no guarantee your property will be as described.

BAD AIRBNB!

My host cancelled with less than 48 hours to go. This was nice house at Cudjoe Key, near Key West. We had airline tickets, and thousands of dollars of activities paid for, and my granddaughters were ready to go, so I had to find something else. Well, Key West is a super hot spot for Spring Break. Airbnb offered to help and then suggested three alternative rentals: one would have cost me an additional $15,000, one was $10,000 more, and the last one was a trailer--a trailer! So, I found and equivalent house. It was $3000 more, which is pretty amazing for Key West during Spring Break. Airbnb only gave me $873.52, so I was out of pocket $2214.13 to get the new rental. I told them that it wasn't fair and they should cover the full amount...but I would be happy splitting it with them. They refused. IN MY OPINION THAT IS NOT FAIR. I reserved an paid for a house...I should get one for the money I paid.

BAD AIRBNB!
Booked though air bnb. 10 days before my holiday the host cancelled the booking. If you're looking for secure bookings air bnb isn't where it's at.

The platform is just annoying. From verification procedures to communication, everything about the platform is just frustrating. In my opinion, the entire platform is a complete failure. The only reason it is so widespread is simply that it was one of the first platforms of its kind. The customer service is terrible and doesn‚Äôt understand a word. Even the verification process alone takes a really long time. I am thoroughly and extremely dissatisfied with the entire platform.

We booked an Airbnb on September 2, 2024, for a planned family vacation scheduled for July 12‚Äì19, 2025. Sadly, just two weeks after booking, my mother suffered a seizure and was diagnosed with a glioblastoma brain tumor‚Äîa devastating and aggressive condition.

While we initially hoped she‚Äôd still be able to make the trip after surgery and treatment, her condition worsened. My father canceled the reservation on February 24, 2025‚Äîwell within the host‚Äôs posted policy, which stated cancellations made by July 5, 2025 would receive a 50% refund of nightly rates and cleaning fees.

Since we had only paid 50% of the total cost ($6,213.82), we expected a refund of that amount. Unfortunately, that didn‚Äôt happen.

The host, Tory, was unwilling to work with us. My father offered medical documentation‚Äîshe declined. She originally said we‚Äôd receive a full refund, then later claimed she was unaware that Airbnb‚Äôs payment plan policy overrides her posted cancellation terms. Eventually, she said we‚Äôd only get a refund if she‚Äôs able to rebook the week‚Äîno guarantee, just a conditional promise.

We were then told by Airbnb that because we used a payment plan, we were not eligible for any refund, despite canceling well in advance and within the stated policy window.

I spent over two hours on the phone with a kind and empathetic customer service manager, who admitted our situation warranted a refund. But he ultimately said he couldn‚Äôt issue one due to internal policy restrictions.

This experience revealed a serious flaw in Airbnb‚Äôs system: there is no clear, compassionate process for families dealing with real emergencies‚Äîeven when the host‚Äôs terms suggest otherwise.

Instead of support, we were met with rigid policies, conflicting information, and a host who changed her story. We‚Äôre not asking for special treatment‚Äîjust basic fairness and human decency. Airbnb failed us when we needed compassion the most.

I‚Äôve reached out directly to Airbnb CEO Brian Chesky in hopes that he‚Äôll step in and do the right thing for our family.

The support team confirmed that the review could be removed, but due to a technical issue, they were unable to process it at that time. For days, I have been explaining that I have evidence proving the review is unfair and that a support agent has already acknowledged this. However, the review still has not been removed.

According to the new policy, only a team called the "Special Team" can handle such cases. However, there is no direct way to contact them. They only provide a form link, and despite submitting it multiple times and informing them about it, I keep receiving the same generic response. It seems like everyone is repeating the same scripted replies, and it is impossible to find someone who genuinely takes responsibility for the issue. If you are treated unfairly, you are simply left to deal with it, with no real solution in sight.

I am a faithful AIRBNB customer. In general, it works. However, I had a host cancel 2 days before a reservation was due to start, putting me in a tremendous bind and cost in me $700 additional dollars to get the only remaining property that met my needs. I cannot review the host, and while AIRBNB states that it will ‚Äúcost the host‚Äù, that have no consideration for the person who has been cancelled. I managed to wrangle a small amount of compensation from AIRBNB, but there is not nearly enough protection for renters. They had the use of my money for that reservation for a full year and cancelled with impunity. Beware!!

I've been a host with them for over five years now, and I've definitely learned a lot along the way! One thing I‚Äôve noticed is that the focus often seems to be on the guests.

For instance, there was a situation where a pump broke down due to unforeseen circumstances, and the guidelines they have‚Äîwhat they call "community standards"‚Äîwere used to navigate that challenge. I had a guest who decided to take off his trousers and insisted on staying, even when I needed to assess the situation because of a burst pipe caused by the dry season. Although Airbnb offered him the option to relocate, he felt there wasn't enough communication from their side.

In the end, I made the decision to cancel his reservation, which I felt was the right choice.

Unfortunately, this isn‚Äôt the first bump in the road I've faced. During Covid, I had a guest who left quite a mess, and while I received only $80 in compensation, I was faced with potential repercussions myself. Sometimes it feels like the fees can be quite high as well!

Overall, while there have been challenges, I still find hosting to be a rewarding experience!

Airbnb website glitched and closed our payment deadline 2 days early - this meant we lost half of our payment and the booking was cancelled. Well well I knew they were not popular in certain quarters but these ratings says it all. I am writing as a host though I have used them many times as a guest too.
Airbnb look after themselves and only themselves! Sound familiar? Sure I‚Äôve heard that in the news about someone else recently ü§£. They have recently removed our super host rating for no good reason.
Their thinking is that now we have dropped from 4 to one property with only a summer season to let ( ie 12 weeks or so) we do not meet their silly criteria anymore whereby one must rent more than 10 visits (1 day or 2 weeks makes no odds) per year. Our Villa is sold out all summer mostly by Airbnb but many bookings are 2 or 3 weeks so we don‚Äôt meet their target! 5* or not, (we actually had 5* on all our properties until we sold them short while ago) we no longer qualify. How crazy is that? Won‚Äôt be with them for much longer me thinks, especially in view of these customer ratings it looks like there is little point anyway. Shame, was once a good company.

All the reviews are true. Airbnb user for more than 10 years and i have constantly been in a position where Airbnb side with the host. I'm hoping for the days of registered b and bs to come back. These guys are getting worse, causing homelessness was bad enough.
I am not one for expecting others to be responsible for when things in my life go wrong. Equally, I am responsible and considerate to others, especially business owners. Needless to say, after the final booking I have in April,I won't be using them ever again. Also,their fees are absurd. You get charged cleaning fees when no cleaning is done. The host came out and cleaned the shower but text to explain they couldn‚Äôt sort the tv until the last day which was too late and with having 3 kids this wasn‚Äôt great. The host claimed everything was fixed and I provided proof it wasn‚Äôt but they offended me by saying the favoured the host.

Will not use again!!!

We recently had a terrible experience with Airbnb, where we were wrongfully charged $368.86 for alleged damages after our stay. Despite having no proof that we caused the damage, Airbnb automatically sided with the host and attempted to charge our credit card without our consent.

Why This Is Unfair:
1. No proof of damage: We repeatedly asked for time-stamped photos or other conclusive evidence that we caused the alleged damage, but Airbnb failed to provide anything substantial.
2. We already paid $2,228 for our 3-night stay at a rate higher than the market price ‚Äì This included a $140 cleaning fee, yet Airbnb still attempted to charge us an additional $100 for ‚Äúextra cleaning.‚Äù This seems like an unfair way to double-charge guests.
3. Zero fair dispute process ‚Äì Airbnb‚Äôs dispute system is one-sided. Guests are held liable without real evidence, and once Airbnb makes a decision, there is no proper way to appeal or escalate the case.
4. Stressful, biased & unethical practices ‚Äì Airbnb clearly favors the hosts over guests throughout the process. This experience has caused significant emotional and physical stress as we have been forced to fight an unfair charge instead of enjoying our trip. Airbnb‚Äôs handling of this has made us question their customer service and trustworthiness.

Beware Before Booking on Airbnb!
‚Ä¢ If a host falsely claims damage, Airbnb may automatically charge you without proof.
‚Ä¢ Even if you dispute it, Airbnb‚Äôs system is stacked against guests.
‚Ä¢ Their customer service offers no real recourse‚Äîonce they decide, they ignore guest complaints.

We will not use Airbnb again unless they change their policies to protect guests from false or unfair charges. If you‚Äôre considering booking, be aware that you could be held liable for damages without evidence or a fair process to defend yourself.

We strongly urge Airbnb to:
‚úî Stop charging guests without sufficient proof.
‚úî Revise their dispute process to allow fair appeals.
‚úî Provide better transparency in damage claims.

If you‚Äôre reading this, think twice before booking on Airbnb! They prioritize hosts over guests, even when the claims are unfair.

I used Airbnb six times in the last two months, and on three separate occasions, I was left stranded because the host either didn‚Äôt respond or failed to provide access to the property. The worst experience was on New Year‚Äôs Eve in Paris. I arrived at my Airbnb and attempted to contact the host numerous times, receiving no response. I was left standing outside in -4¬∞C for hours, desperately trying to find alternative accommodation. Given that it was one of the busiest nights of the year, every hotel was either fully booked or outrageously expensive. How is Airbnb not verifying that their hosts still own or have access to the properties they advertise? They charge enormous fees‚Äîwhat exactly are they for if not basic verification?

The second and third failures happened within 24 hours of each other.
On one occasion, I arrived at the Airbnb at the designated check-in time, called and messaged the host repeatedly, and received no response for hours. I was forced to book a last-minute hotel late at night. Later, I found out the host had been sick and ‚Äúfell asleep.‚Äù While frustrating, at least it was an explanation.

However, the next night was even worse. I had booked a hotel through Airbnb, which had a 24-hour reception, so I assumed nothing could possibly go wrong. How wrong I was. After traveling across the city in a taxi, I arrived at the hotel to find a tiny sign on the door stating: ‚ÄúClosed for one month for renovations.‚Äù I had made the booking almost exactly one month prior‚Äîmeaning Airbnb had allowed me to pay in full for a completely shut-down hotel. How does that even happen?

Each time, Airbnb refunded what I had originally paid, but that did nothing to cover the hundreds of euros in additional costs I incurred. I booked through Airbnb to try and save money, but in the end, it cost me far more than if I had just booked hotels directly.

I will be uninstalling Airbnb and never using it again. My advice? Use Booking.com or any other platform. I‚Äôve never had issues with them, and after this absolute disaster, I wouldn‚Äôt trust Airbnb with a single cent.

Never had problems before but trying to book and there is a new verification process. Impossible to use. Spent over half an hour going round in circles. Very poor.

I'm also very nervous about providing confidential information like a passport, especially since it is an American company where you can't be sure that your privacy and confidential data is properly protected.

Airbnb saw all the interest and put the price up!!
So I went direct to the host and got it for the original price..
If you are looking for a place to share, don't share the airbnb link - just copy the details and send those.

We have booked 2 properties in Wales and both were lacking. We have had great host in the 1st one, so we've overlooked maintenance issues. 2nd stay was horrific, really dated property, not following basic H&S (electric heater and extension lead in bathroom!). We have raised issues with host and were faced with harrasment over messages, to the point that I had to turn volume on my phone- I was bombarded with messages late into the night, even when I have asked her to stop and told her I was dealing with AirBnB support. Howere, the support seems to be for the host only - as a guest you are completely ignored, even after raising safety issues. Messages from the support team were also hostile, demanding additional payments, even though we've paid in full!! We are still waiting for a refund as we've only stayed 2 out of 5 nights ( no property heating or hot water during Feb in Wales). And if your review is honest they just remove it. We will definitely never use this booking platform again, as there are cheaper and safer options.

DO NOT USE AIRBNB. Decided to hold my nose and try to use this excrescence of a company to book a holiday cottage in Ireland which looked very nice. My colleagues and I had a very disappointing experience with Airbnb, and as a result, all of us made the decision to discontinue using their services. What happened was that their vendor (apartment owner) had cancelled at the last moment (late in the evening), and it was too late to book another unit. So we contacted Airbnb and gave their staff an opportunity to find a replacement property. This was not done (due to late hour); and instead we were expressly told by Airbnb representative to go to a hotel. It was clearly discussed that it‚Äôs a more expensive option because we needed at least three rooms. This was clearly understood -- and we proceeded to do as instructed.

Subsequently, very surprisingly, Airbnb refused to reimburse the costs that we had to endure associated with the three hotel rooms (in excess of the original budget, per the cost of the apartment I had contracted from Airbnb). I became aware that Airbnb collected $50 as penalty from the reneging owner/vendor. Strangely, however, Airbnb didn't even offer that amount towards my unplanned costs that night (caused by the breach/cancellation). Needless to say, this is dishonest/unacceptable, so we‚Äôll not work with Airbnb in the future. Fortunately, alternatives do exist.

From a landlord perspective.

There's a lot on here from guests who've had bad experiences, but wanted to warn hosts too.

When AirBnb works, it's great - the review system generally keep both hosts and guests (I've been both) "honest", AKA reasonable.

But when something goes wrong...

I had a guest want to stay for several months. She complained about WiFi and a few other things during her stay, not without justification. So I was surprised a few weeks later when she booked another long-ish stay, and warned her that the Wi-Fi would still be problematic.

To cut a long and painful story short, she's effectively now squatting in my AirBnb (the long stays should have been a warning - why not an AST?), and AirBnb are precisely zero help. They spent 5 days trying to contact her and she simply ignored them. They say I've no right to make her leave even though there's safety issues (the wood-burning stove chimney is overdue its annual sweep). She won't allow access to anyone, and keeps a key in the door to stop it being opened.

So to court I go. This may have been the outcome even if AirBnb hadn't been obstructive, but not being permitted access or to evict under their rules? They're always very friendly in the Rio de Janeiro call centre, but it's a useless system once something goes wrong.

1 view because I had to.. anyone who calls needing you to pay via asda gift vouchers proceed with high caution. Dirty scammers will try their luck. Thankfully our bank paid back and I do hope these vile people are caught, but chances are as always, they'll move on to their next victim

Absolutely disgusting fraudulent company I spent ¬£405 on weekend away in a luxury trailer this is still been advertised on the site to this day we booked oaid got our confirmation through ect only 5 mins later get a message from the owner Sayinh the site is sold out and has been for some time not sure why it‚Äôs still been advertised contact air b&b for a refund to then have to do that to then be told il get a refund in the next 10-15 working days so now we‚Äôre out of pocket for god knows how long so due to lack of funds have to cancel our weekend away

Hi I'm an English solicitor (lawyer) based in Bangkok. I live in Condo Building and like 99% of the residents we own our homes.
Under Thai law (which is very strict) daily renting of homes is illegal under 30 days. To do Airbnb the host must apply for a hotel licence. Over the past few years Airbnb in our building has increased and causing misery and distress to the residents. We have formed a residents committee and are involving the police.
Airbnb publicise an information sheet on Thailand which is wholly inadequate as it does not spell out that it is illegal here. What more is there to say? Guests should not book in Thailand, Airbnb are being irresponsible and putting profits before local laws. Let me repeat: Airbnb is illegal. Hosts of a condo unit cannot get a hotel licence as a condo is not a hotel.
This is our home and every day the residents have to do battle with Airbnb guests. What do Airbnb do? Nothing as they are happy making the profits. Why does Airbnb not check the Thai laws and ban the platform in Thailand unless a host (such as a hotelier) can produce their hotel licence. I doubt they will reply or it will be a template response: "we will consider all your points seriously as we are aware of our online worldwide responsibilities " which is double speak for " get lost loser, we have money to make."
Please Airbnb do the right thing here adopt a different paradigm for Thailand before something seriously goes wrong as we are at breaking point.

Looking back I realized it was all a grand scheme to take all the money I had at the time.

I've been running a holiday business in Greece for twenty years; villas in olive groves with expansive sea and mountain views. Peace and tranquility. As much estate bottled extra virgin olive oil as you can consume. Mine is a legal business: tax paying, tourist authority and chamber of conference registered. I'm a five star host, but why is AirBnB so difficult to work with? Let me have a look at the platform reviews on Trustpilot I thought, out of interest. The answer is, AirBnB get 1.3 stars out of 5. Not good. Reading the reviews, I am disappointed, disillusioned even, although I can understand and directly relate to how the platform works only in the interest of the platform itself, uniformly (seemingly) against the interests of both hosts and guests. It's a difficult business, demanding skill, knowledge and investment, something that AirBnB simply don't seem to understand or bother with. Currently AirBnB is a titan like Uber and Amazon, sweeping everything else aside. Unpopular titans don't tend to last unless they learn, change, understand and appreciate their business beyond simply profit margins. This is something hosts understand very well. It's been difficult and not very satisfactory, my period on the AirBnB platform. There's too much reliance on AI it seems, too much faceless, nameless automation; no personal service, no attention to detail. They strongly encourage reviews of hosts and guests; hypocritically calling this a community and yet they don't like, don't encourage, don't react to or respond to constructive feedback themselves, not of the platform AirBnB. Disappointing is how I can describe my dealings with the platform, AirBnB.

In total we‚Äôve had to pay ¬£176 out of our pockets due to Airbnb‚Äôs host cancelling on us, which they will not pay us back for in compensation. I‚Äôm then offered a ‚Ç¨100 voucher by one staff member, only to be pushed to a more senior member who can only offer $50?! Just complete mess with different currencies and their lack of care to even attempt to cover the full cost.

It‚Äôs disgusting the lack of care they have for customers. I‚Äôm actually stunned I‚Äôm having to fight for compensation when we were the ones who were inconvenienced. Avoid using them at all costs!

I had an extremely disappointing experience with Airbnb that has left me frustrated and concerned. During my stay at a property booked through Airbnb, a large tree branch fell and damaged my car due to the host's lack of property maintenance. The situation was not just inconvenient‚Äîit was dangerous. The branch fell in a high-traffic area where children were present, and it could have caused serious harm if it had landed on someone.

I immediately reported the incident to both the host and Airbnb, providing photos and evidence of additional hazardous branches on the property. The host dismissed the issue, refused to take responsibility, and did nothing to ensure safety for future guests.

I reached out to Airbnb for support, but the process has been nothing short of a nightmare. My claim was passed between ‚Äúspecialized teams‚Äù more than a dozen times, with over 100 messages and several phone calls. Despite assurances that I would be reimbursed, my claim disappeared from their system, and I have yet to receive a resolution months later. This lack of accountability and poor customer service is unacceptable. Airbnb not only failed to address a clear safety hazard but also neglected to follow through on their promise to resolve the matter.

I want to warn others about Airbnb‚Äôs inability to handle serious issues effectively. If you encounter problems, don‚Äôt expect them to take responsibility or prioritize your safety.

Recently stayed in a property where the host said ‚Äúno smoking‚Äù but the house smelt like stale cigarette smoke. From the fact the smell was embedded into everything makes me think that the host is a heavy smoker.
The host admitted that smoking was taking place within an area of the premises, yet sees no problem with advertising the property as non-smoking and that they cannot smell it.
I moved out the next day and Airbnb were very helpful in the process. I use Airbnb a lot and it‚Äôs comforting to know that they have a process for handling situations like this.
